trans-unit.source: Troubleshooting Service Fabric application upgrades
trans-unit.target: Troubleshooting Service Fabric application upgrades

trans-unit.source: This article covers some common issues around upgrading a Service Fabric application and how to resolve them.
trans-unit.target: This article covers some common issues around upgrading a Service Fabric application and how to resolve them.

trans-unit.source: This article covers some of the common issues around upgrading a Service Fabric application and how to resolve them.
trans-unit.target: This article covers some of the common issues around upgrading a Service Fabric application and how to resolve them.

trans-unit.source: When an upgrade fails, the output of the Get-ServiceFabricApplicationUpgrade command will contain some additional information for debugging the failure.
trans-unit.target: When an upgrade fails, the output of the Get-ServiceFabricApplicationUpgrade command will contain some additional information for debugging the failure.

trans-unit.source: This information can be used to:
trans-unit.target: This information can be used to:

trans-unit.source: Identify the failure type
trans-unit.target: Identify the failure type

trans-unit.source: Identify the failure reason
trans-unit.target: Identify the failure reason

trans-unit.source: Isolate the failing component(s) for further investigation
trans-unit.target: Isolate the failing component(s) for further investigation

trans-unit.source: This information will be available as soon as Service Fabric detects the failure regardless of whether the FailureAction is to rollback or suspend the upgrade.
trans-unit.target: This information will be available as soon as Service Fabric detects the failure regardless of whether the FailureAction is to rollback or suspend the upgrade.

trans-unit.source: In the output of Get-ServiceFabricApplicationUpgrade, FailureTimestampUtc identifies the timestamp (in UTC) at which an upgrade failure was detected by Service Fabric and the FailureAction was triggered.
trans-unit.target: In the output of Get-ServiceFabricApplicationUpgrade, FailureTimestampUtc identifies the timestamp (in UTC) at which an upgrade failure was detected by Service Fabric and the FailureAction was triggered.

trans-unit.source: The FailureReason identifies one of three potential high-level causes of the failure:
trans-unit.target: The FailureReason identifies one of three potential high-level causes of the failure:

trans-unit.source: UpgradeDomainTimeout - Indicates that a particular upgrade domain took too long to complete and UpgradeDomainTimeout expired.
trans-unit.target: UpgradeDomainTimeout - Indicates that a particular upgrade domain took too long to complete and UpgradeDomainTimeout expired.

trans-unit.source: OverallUpgradeTimeout - Indicates that the overall upgrade took too long to complete and UpgradeTimeout expired.
trans-unit.target: OverallUpgradeTimeout - Indicates that the overall upgrade took too long to complete and UpgradeTimeout expired.

trans-unit.source: HealthCheck - Indicates that after upgrading an Upgrade Domain, the application remained unhealthy according to the specified health policies and HealthCheckRetryTimeout expired.
trans-unit.target: HealthCheck - Indicates that after upgrading an Upgrade Domain, the application remained unhealthy according to the specified health policies and HealthCheckRetryTimeout expired.

trans-unit.source: These entries will only show up in the output when the upgrade fails and starts rolling back.
trans-unit.target: These entries will only show up in the output when the upgrade fails and starts rolling back.

trans-unit.source: Further information will be displayed depending on the type of the failure.
trans-unit.target: Further information will be displayed depending on the type of the failure.

trans-unit.source: Upgrade timeout failures are most commonly caused by service availability issues.
trans-unit.target: Upgrade timeout failures are most commonly caused by service availability issues.

trans-unit.source: The output below is typical of upgrades where service replicas or instances fail to start in the new code version.
trans-unit.target: The output below is typical of upgrades where service replicas or instances fail to start in the new code version.

trans-unit.source: The UpgradeDomainProgressAtFailure field captures a snapshot of any pending upgrade work at the time of failure.
trans-unit.target: The UpgradeDomainProgressAtFailure field captures a snapshot of any pending upgrade work at the time of failure.

trans-unit.source: ~~~ PS D:\temp> Get-ServiceFabricApplicationUpgrade fabric:/DemoApp
trans-unit.target: ~~~ PS D:\temp> Get-ServiceFabricApplicationUpgrade fabric:/DemoApp

trans-unit.source: ApplicationName : fabric:/DemoApp ApplicationTypeName : DemoAppType TargetApplicationTypeVersion : v2 ApplicationParameters : {} StartTimestampUtc : 4/14/2015 9:26:38 PM FailureTimestampUtc : 4/14/2015 9:27:05 PM FailureReason : UpgradeDomainTimeout UpgradeDomainProgressAtFailure : MYUD1
trans-unit.target: ApplicationName : fabric:/DemoApp ApplicationTypeName : DemoAppType TargetApplicationTypeVersion : v2 ApplicationParameters : {} StartTimestampUtc : 4/14/2015 9:26:38 PM FailureTimestampUtc : 4/14/2015 9:27:05 PM FailureReason : UpgradeDomainTimeout UpgradeDomainProgressAtFailure : MYUD1

trans-unit.source: In this example, we can see that the upgrade failed at upgrade domain MYUD1 and two partitions (744c8d9f-1d26-417e-a60e-cd48f5c098f0 and 4b43f4d8-b26b-424e-9307-7a7a62e79750) were stuck, unable to place primary replicas (WaitForPrimaryPlacement) on target nodes Node1 and Node4.
trans-unit.target: In this example, we can see that the upgrade failed at upgrade domain MYUD1 and two partitions (744c8d9f-1d26-417e-a60e-cd48f5c098f0 and 4b43f4d8-b26b-424e-9307-7a7a62e79750) were stuck, unable to place primary replicas (WaitForPrimaryPlacement) on target nodes Node1 and Node4.

trans-unit.source: The Get-ServiceFabricNode command can be used to verify that these two nodes are in upgrade domain MYUD1.
trans-unit.target: The Get-ServiceFabricNode command can be used to verify that these two nodes are in upgrade domain MYUD1.

trans-unit.source: The UpgradePhase says PostUpgradeSafetyCheck, which means that these safety checks are occurring after all nodes in the upgrade domain had finished upgrading.
trans-unit.target: The UpgradePhase says PostUpgradeSafetyCheck, which means that these safety checks are occurring after all nodes in the upgrade domain had finished upgrading.

trans-unit.source: All this information combined points to a potential issue with the new version of the application code.
trans-unit.target: All this information combined points to a potential issue with the new version of the application code.

trans-unit.source: The most common issues are service errors in the open or promotion to primary code paths.
trans-unit.target: The most common issues are service errors in the open or promotion to primary code paths.

trans-unit.source: An UpgradePhase of PreUpgradeSafetyCheck means there were issues preparing the upgrade domain before actually performing the upgrade.
trans-unit.target: An UpgradePhase of PreUpgradeSafetyCheck means there were issues preparing the upgrade domain before actually performing the upgrade.

trans-unit.source: The most common issues in this case are service errors in the close or demotion from primary code paths.
trans-unit.target: The most common issues in this case are service errors in the close or demotion from primary code paths.

trans-unit.source: The current UpgradeState is RollingBackCompleted, so the original upgrade must have been performed with a rollback FailureAction, which automatically rolled back the upgrade upon failure.
trans-unit.target: The current UpgradeState is RollingBackCompleted, so the original upgrade must have been performed with a rollback FailureAction, which automatically rolled back the upgrade upon failure.

trans-unit.source: If the original upgrade had been performed with a manual FailureAction, then the upgrade would instead be in a suspended state to allow live debugging of the application.
trans-unit.target: If the original upgrade had been performed with a manual FailureAction, then the upgrade would instead be in a suspended state to allow live debugging of the application.

trans-unit.source: Health check failures can be triggered by a variety of additional issues that can happen after all nodes in an upgrade domain finish upgrading, passing all safety checks.
trans-unit.target: Health check failures can be triggered by a variety of additional issues that can happen after all nodes in an upgrade domain finish upgrading, passing all safety checks.

trans-unit.source: The output below is typical of an upgrade failure due to failed health checks.
trans-unit.target: The output below is typical of an upgrade failure due to failed health checks.

trans-unit.source: The UnhealthyEvaluations field captures a snapshot of all failing health checks at the time of the upgrade failure according the user-specified Health Policy.
trans-unit.target: The UnhealthyEvaluations field captures a snapshot of all failing health checks at the time of the upgrade failure according the user-specified Health Policy.

trans-unit.source: ~~~ PS D:\temp> Get-ServiceFabricApplicationUpgrade fabric:/DemoApp
trans-unit.target: ~~~ PS D:\temp> Get-ServiceFabricApplicationUpgrade fabric:/DemoApp

trans-unit.source: ApplicationName : fabric:/DemoApp ApplicationTypeName : DemoAppType TargetApplicationTypeVersion : v4 ApplicationParameters : {} StartTimestampUtc : 4/24/2015 2:42:31 AM UpgradeState : RollingForwardPending UpgradeDuration : 00:00:27 CurrentUpgradeDomainDuration : 00:00:27 NextUpgradeDomain : MYUD2 UpgradeDomainsStatus : { "MYUD1" = "Completed"; "MYUD2" = "Pending"; "MYUD3" = "Pending" } UnhealthyEvaluations : Unhealthy services: 50% (2/4), ServiceType='PersistedServiceType', MaxPercentUnhealthyServices=0%.
trans-unit.target: ApplicationName : fabric:/DemoApp ApplicationTypeName : DemoAppType TargetApplicationTypeVersion : v4 ApplicationParameters : {} StartTimestampUtc : 4/24/2015 2:42:31 AM UpgradeState : RollingForwardPending UpgradeDuration : 00:00:27 CurrentUpgradeDomainDuration : 00:00:27 NextUpgradeDomain : MYUD2 UpgradeDomainsStatus : { "MYUD1" = "Completed"; "MYUD2" = "Pending"; "MYUD3" = "Pending" } UnhealthyEvaluations : Unhealthy services: 50% (2/4), ServiceType='PersistedServiceType', MaxPercentUnhealthyServices=0%.

trans-unit.source: UpgradeKind : Rolling RollingUpgradeMode : Monitored FailureAction : Manual ForceRestart : False UpgradeReplicaSetCheckTimeout : 49710.06:28:15 HealthCheckWaitDuration : 00:00:00 HealthCheckStableDuration : 00:00:10 HealthCheckRetryTimeout : 00:00:10 UpgradeDomainTimeout : 10675199.02:48:05.4775807 UpgradeTimeout : 10675199.02:48:05.4775807 ConsiderWarningAsError : MaxPercentUnhealthyPartitionsPerService : MaxPercentUnhealthyReplicasPerPartition : MaxPercentUnhealthyServices : MaxPercentUnhealthyDeployedApplications : ServiceTypeHealthPolicyMap : ~~~
trans-unit.target: UpgradeKind : Rolling RollingUpgradeMode : Monitored FailureAction : Manual ForceRestart : False UpgradeReplicaSetCheckTimeout : 49710.06:28:15 HealthCheckWaitDuration : 00:00:00 HealthCheckStableDuration : 00:00:10 HealthCheckRetryTimeout : 00:00:10 UpgradeDomainTimeout : 10675199.02:48:05.4775807 UpgradeTimeout : 10675199.02:48:05.4775807 ConsiderWarningAsError : MaxPercentUnhealthyPartitionsPerService : MaxPercentUnhealthyReplicasPerPartition : MaxPercentUnhealthyServices : MaxPercentUnhealthyDeployedApplications : ServiceTypeHealthPolicyMap : ~~~

trans-unit.source: Investigating health check failures first requires an understanding of the Service Fabric health model, but even without such an in-depth understanding, we can see that two services are unhealthy: fabric:/DemoApp/Svc3 and fabric:/DemoApp/Svc2 along with the error health reports ("InjectedFault" in this case).
trans-unit.target: Investigating health check failures first requires an understanding of the Service Fabric health model, but even without such an in-depth understanding, we can see that two services are unhealthy: fabric:/DemoApp/Svc3 and fabric:/DemoApp/Svc2 along with the error health reports ("InjectedFault" in this case).

trans-unit.source: In this example, 2 out of 4 services are unhealthy, below the default target of 0% unhealthy (MaxPercentUnhealthyServices).
trans-unit.target: In this example, 2 out of 4 services are unhealthy, below the default target of 0% unhealthy (MaxPercentUnhealthyServices).

trans-unit.source: The upgrade was suspended upon failing by specifying a FailureAction of manual when starting the upgrade, so we can investigate the live system in the failed state if desired before taking any further actions.
trans-unit.target: The upgrade was suspended upon failing by specifying a FailureAction of manual when starting the upgrade, so we can investigate the live system in the failed state if desired before taking any further actions.

trans-unit.source: With a rollback FailureAction, there is no recovery needed since the upgrade will automatically rollback upon failing.
trans-unit.target: With a rollback FailureAction, there is no recovery needed since the upgrade will automatically rollback upon failing.

trans-unit.source: With a manual FailureAction, there are several recovery options:
trans-unit.target: With a manual FailureAction, there are several recovery options:

trans-unit.source: Manually trigger a rollback
trans-unit.target: Manually trigger a rollback

trans-unit.source: Proceed through the remainder of the upgrade manually
trans-unit.target: Proceed through the remainder of the upgrade manually

trans-unit.source: Resume the monitored upgrade
trans-unit.target: Resume the monitored upgrade

trans-unit.source: The Start-ServiceFabricApplicationRollback command can be used at any time to start rolling back the application.
trans-unit.target: The Start-ServiceFabricApplicationRollback command can be used at any time to start rolling back the application.

trans-unit.source: Once the command returns successfully, the rollback request has been registered in the system and will start shortly.
trans-unit.target: Once the command returns successfully, the rollback request has been registered in the system and will start shortly.

trans-unit.source: The Resume-ServiceFabricApplicationUpgrade command can be used to proceed through the remainder of the upgrade manually, one upgrade domain at a time.
trans-unit.target: The Resume-ServiceFabricApplicationUpgrade command can be used to proceed through the remainder of the upgrade manually, one upgrade domain at a time.

trans-unit.source: In this mode, only safety checks will be performed by the system - no more health checks will be performed.
trans-unit.target: In this mode, only safety checks will be performed by the system - no more health checks will be performed.

trans-unit.source: This command can only be used when the UpgradeState shows RollingForwardPending, which means that the current upgrade domain has finished upgrading but the next upgrade domain has not started yet (pending).
trans-unit.target: This command can only be used when the UpgradeState shows RollingForwardPending, which means that the current upgrade domain has finished upgrading but the next upgrade domain has not started yet (pending).

trans-unit.source: The Update-ServiceFabricApplicationUpgrade command can be used to resume the monitored upgrade with both safety and health checks being performed.
trans-unit.target: The Update-ServiceFabricApplicationUpgrade command can be used to resume the monitored upgrade with both safety and health checks being performed.

trans-unit.source: ~~~ PS D:\temp> Update-ServiceFabricApplicationUpgrade fabric:/DemoApp -UpgradeMode Monitored
trans-unit.target: ~~~ PS D:\temp> Update-ServiceFabricApplicationUpgrade fabric:/DemoApp -UpgradeMode Monitored

trans-unit.source: UpgradeMode : Monitored ForceRestart : UpgradeReplicaSetCheckTimeout : FailureAction : HealthCheckWaitDuration : HealthCheckStableDuration : HealthCheckRetryTimeout : UpgradeTimeout : UpgradeDomainTimeout : ConsiderWarningAsError : MaxPercentUnhealthyPartitionsPerService : MaxPercentUnhealthyReplicasPerPartition : MaxPercentUnhealthyServices : MaxPercentUnhealthyDeployedApplications : ServiceTypeHealthPolicyMap :
trans-unit.target: UpgradeMode : Monitored ForceRestart : UpgradeReplicaSetCheckTimeout : FailureAction : HealthCheckWaitDuration : HealthCheckStableDuration : HealthCheckRetryTimeout : UpgradeTimeout : UpgradeDomainTimeout : ConsiderWarningAsError : MaxPercentUnhealthyPartitionsPerService : MaxPercentUnhealthyReplicasPerPartition : MaxPercentUnhealthyServices : MaxPercentUnhealthyDeployedApplications : ServiceTypeHealthPolicyMap :

trans-unit.source: PS D:\temp> ~~~
trans-unit.target: PS D:\temp> ~~~

trans-unit.source: The upgrade will continue from the upgrade domain where it was last suspended and use the same upgrade parameters and health policies as before.
trans-unit.target: The upgrade will continue from the upgrade domain where it was last suspended and use the same upgrade parameters and health policies as before.

trans-unit.source: If needed, any of the upgrade parameters and health policies shown in the output above can be changed in the same command when resuming the upgrade.
trans-unit.target: If needed, any of the upgrade parameters and health policies shown in the output above can be changed in the same command when resuming the upgrade.

trans-unit.source: In this example, the upgrade was resumed in Monitored mode leaving all other parameters unchanged, thereby using the same parameters and health policies as before.
trans-unit.target: In this example, the upgrade was resumed in Monitored mode leaving all other parameters unchanged, thereby using the same parameters and health policies as before.

trans-unit.source: Possible Cause 1:
trans-unit.target: Possible Cause 1:

trans-unit.source: Service Fabric translates all percentages into actual numbers of entities (e.g. replicas, partitions, and services) for health evaluation and always rounds up to the nearest number of whole entities.
trans-unit.target: Service Fabric translates all percentages into actual numbers of entities (e.g. replicas, partitions, and services) for health evaluation and always rounds up to the nearest number of whole entities.

trans-unit.source: For example, if the maximum MaxPercentUnhealthyReplicasPerPartition is 21% and there are 5 replicas, then Service Fabric will allow up to 2 replicas (i.e., Math.Ceiling (5\*0.21)) to be unhealthy when evaluating partition health.
trans-unit.target: For example, if the maximum MaxPercentUnhealthyReplicasPerPartition is 21% and there are 5 replicas, then Service Fabric will allow up to 2 replicas (i.e., Math.Ceiling (5\*0.21)) to be unhealthy when evaluating partition health.

trans-unit.source: Health policies should be set accordingly to account for this.
trans-unit.target: Health policies should be set accordingly to account for this.

trans-unit.source: Possible Cause 2:
trans-unit.target: Possible Cause 2:

trans-unit.source: Health policies are specified in terms of percentages of total services and not specific service instances.
trans-unit.target: Health policies are specified in terms of percentages of total services and not specific service instances.

trans-unit.source: For example, before an upgrade, assume that an application has four service instances A, B, C, and D, where service D is unhealthy but with no significant impact on the application.
trans-unit.target: For example, before an upgrade, assume that an application has four service instances A, B, C, and D, where service D is unhealthy but with no significant impact on the application.

trans-unit.source: We want to ignore the known unhealthy service D during upgrade and set the parameter MaxPercentUnhealthyServices to be 25% assuming only A, B, and C need to be healthy.
trans-unit.target: We want to ignore the known unhealthy service D during upgrade and set the parameter MaxPercentUnhealthyServices to be 25% assuming only A, B, and C need to be healthy.

trans-unit.source: However, during the upgrade, D may become healthy while C becomes unhealthy.
trans-unit.target: However, during the upgrade, D may become healthy while C becomes unhealthy.

trans-unit.source: The upgrade would still complete successfully in this case since only 25% of the services are unhealthy, which might result in unanticipated errors due to C being unexpectedly unhealthy instead of D. In this situation, D should be modeled as a different Service Type from A, B, and C. Since health policies can be specified on a per-Service Type basis, this would allow applying different unhealthy percentage thresholds to different services based on their roles in the application.
trans-unit.target: The upgrade would still complete successfully in this case since only 25% of the services are unhealthy, which might result in unanticipated errors due to C being unexpectedly unhealthy instead of D. In this situation, D should be modeled as a different Service Type from A, B, and C. Since health policies can be specified on a per-Service Type basis, this would allow applying different unhealthy percentage thresholds to different services based on their roles in the application.

trans-unit.source: When health policies aren't provided to the upgrade request, they are taken from the ApplicationManifest.xml of the current application version (for example, if upgrading Application X from v1 to v2, application health policies specified for Application X in v1 are used).
trans-unit.target: When health policies aren't provided to the upgrade request, they are taken from the ApplicationManifest.xml of the current application version (for example, if upgrading Application X from v1 to v2, application health policies specified for Application X in v1 are used).

trans-unit.source: If a different health policy should be used for the upgrade, then the policy needs to be specified as part of the application upgrade API call.
trans-unit.target: If a different health policy should be used for the upgrade, then the policy needs to be specified as part of the application upgrade API call.

trans-unit.source: Note that the policies specified as part of the API call only apply for the duration of the upgrade.
trans-unit.target: Note that the policies specified as part of the API call only apply for the duration of the upgrade.

trans-unit.source: Once the upgrade is completed, the policies specified in the ApplicationManifest.xml are used.
trans-unit.target: Once the upgrade is completed, the policies specified in the ApplicationManifest.xml are used.

trans-unit.source: Users may have wondered about what happens if the timeouts are set inconsistently, for example, having an UpgradeTimeout less than the UpgradeDomainTimeout.
trans-unit.target: Users may have wondered about what happens if the timeouts are set inconsistently, for example, having an UpgradeTimeout less than the UpgradeDomainTimeout.

trans-unit.source: The answer is that an error is returned.
trans-unit.target: The answer is that an error is returned.

trans-unit.source: Other cases where this may happen is if UpgradeDomainTimeout is less than the sum of HealthCheckWaitDuration and HealthCheckRetryTimeout or if UpgradeDomainTimeout is less than the sum of HealthCheckWaitDuration and HealthCheckStableDuration.
trans-unit.target: Other cases where this may happen is if UpgradeDomainTimeout is less than the sum of HealthCheckWaitDuration and HealthCheckRetryTimeout or if UpgradeDomainTimeout is less than the sum of HealthCheckWaitDuration and HealthCheckStableDuration.

trans-unit.source: The time it takes for an upgrade to complete is dependent on the various health checks and timeouts specified, which in turn are dependent on the time it takes for your application to upgrade (including copying the package, deploying, and stabilizing).
trans-unit.target: The time it takes for an upgrade to complete is dependent on the various health checks and timeouts specified, which in turn are dependent on the time it takes for your application to upgrade (including copying the package, deploying, and stabilizing).

trans-unit.source: Being too aggressive with timeouts might mean more failed upgrades, and thus starting conservatively with longer timeouts is recommended.
trans-unit.target: Being too aggressive with timeouts might mean more failed upgrades, and thus starting conservatively with longer timeouts is recommended.

trans-unit.source: A quick refresher on how the timeouts interact with the upgrade times:
trans-unit.target: A quick refresher on how the timeouts interact with the upgrade times:

trans-unit.source: Upgrade for a upgrade domain cannot complete faster than HealthCheckWaitDuration + HealthCheckStableDuration.
trans-unit.target: Upgrade for a upgrade domain cannot complete faster than HealthCheckWaitDuration + HealthCheckStableDuration.

trans-unit.source: Upgrade failure cannot occur faster than HealthCheckWaitDuration + HealthCheckRetryTimeout.
trans-unit.target: Upgrade failure cannot occur faster than HealthCheckWaitDuration + HealthCheckRetryTimeout.

trans-unit.source: The upgrade time for a upgrade domain is limited by UpgradeDomainTimeout.
trans-unit.target: The upgrade time for a upgrade domain is limited by UpgradeDomainTimeout.

trans-unit.source: If HealthCheckRetryTimeout and HealthCheckStableDuration are both non-zero and the health of the application keeps switching back and forth, then the upgrade will eventually timeout on UpgradeDomainTimeout.
trans-unit.target: If HealthCheckRetryTimeout and HealthCheckStableDuration are both non-zero and the health of the application keeps switching back and forth, then the upgrade will eventually timeout on UpgradeDomainTimeout.

trans-unit.source: UpgradeDomainTimeout starts counting down once the upgrade for the current upgrade domain begins.
trans-unit.target: UpgradeDomainTimeout starts counting down once the upgrade for the current upgrade domain begins.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Upgrade Tutorial</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Upgrade Tutorial</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Upgrade Parameters</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Advanced Topics</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Data Serialization</linkText><title></title>
